Article/0-0-0-18/single-page-application.html:
Use Nullstack to generate single page applications that can connect to any API or server functions.<\/p>

Single page applications are useful for environments that should not use server-side rendering<\/a>, like native applications.<\/p>

You can easily move your application from SSR to SPA by changing the build command.<\/p> 

npx nullstack build --<\/span>mode=<\/span>spa --<\/span>output=<\/span>spa
<\/code><\/pre>



ðŸ”¥ You must be in a Nullstack project folder to run this command.<\/p>
<\/blockquote>

By default, it will create your single page application in the spa<\/strong> folder you can override this with the --output<\/code> flag.<\/p>

The builder will run your application in production mode and generate an empty index.html that is prepared to become a Nullstack client-only application.<\/p>

The manifest.json<\/a> and the contents of the public folder will be copied into the target folder.<\/p>

On the first visit to your static application the JavaScript bundle will be loaded and start a SPA.<\/p>

On the subsequent requests, Nullstack will push history and update the application state without ever reloading the page.<\/p>

Good Pratices<\/a><\/h2>
You can add a script to your package.json<\/strong> to generate your static website in a custom folder:<\/p>

{<\/span>
  "name"<\/span>:<\/span> "nullstack.github.io"<\/span>,<\/span>
  "scripts"<\/span>:<\/span> {<\/span>
    "start"<\/span>:<\/span> "npx nullstack start"<\/span>,<\/span>
    "build"<\/span>:<\/span> "npx nullstack build --mode=spa --output=web"<\/span>,<\/span>
  }<\/span>
  
  ...<\/span>
}<\/span>

<\/code><\/pre>

Caveats<\/a><\/h2>
In SPA mode both prepare<\/code><\/a> and initiate<\/code><\/a> will always run in the client.
However it is a good pratice to follow SSR patterns in order to be able to easily change the build mode.<\/p>

You can mix modes and request further server functions by pointing worker.api<\/code> and hosting the server bundle in a node.js environment.<\/p>
